author: {'steamid': '76561199483594082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 467, 'playtime_at_review': 852, 'last_played': 1711410274}
review:
Absolutely awesome game, I can totally recommend it! Buy it, play it, love it!

+
- very awesome storytelling (on different levels)
- very good story
- nice, nerdy humor and references
- not too difficult but satisfying puzzles

-
- the collecting might get a bit boring after a while but at least I was in a detective fever and wanted to collect them all (failed)

author: {'steamid': '76561198331087869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 346, 'playtime_at_review': 1175, 'last_played': 1711293214}
review: Be warned that this game ends on a devious cliffhanger that will leave you impatient for the upcoming sequel. But don't worry, the game does solve its central mysteries first - and does so in a satisfying, well-foreshadowed, and immensely clever way. Overall, Jenny LeClue is charming, creative, and an excellent mystery game. 9/10, easily.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075189462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1709666513}
review:
Absolutely incredible!!! I don't think I've enjoyed a game so much in a long time! This is my ideal kind of game; characters that are funny, annoying, emotional - real! 

Alongside an amazing and sometimes trippy art style, great puzzles, and twists that had me genuinely gasping, highly recommend :) I'll be 100% at some point and can't wait for the next one!

author: {'steamid': '76561198129936651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 477, 'playtime_forever': 1606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1606, 'last_played': 1707693927}
review:
Jenny LeClue â€“ Detectivu is a really good detective adventure game, okay then story. Jenny LeClue a popular children's mystery book series that has been loved by all for years, well until recently that is. Unfortunately Jenny LeClueâ€™s adventures have become old hat, outdated and predictable to this new generation of kids who want real danger, adventure and most of all a real mystery, nothing like the childish little adventures that the writer Arthur Finkelton has made for years in his series. 

But Arthur has been given one more chance to breathe new life in his old book series, to have Jenny face a real mystery to have her brain and her courage put to the test and Arthur having to move from the safe comfortable world that he has written for 30 years. To make it something different, something darker something more adventurous and dangerous, to begin this brand new adventure it starts with Jenny LeClueâ€™s first murder case.

Okay then the likes, the story is really good with a good mystery with plenty of twists and turns, it also has plenty of great themes, to start the story kind of breaks the fourth wall what I mean by that is this is a story within a story, Jenny Leclue is a popular book series written by Arthur Finkelton and this is a story about him moving from his comfort zone, doing something bold and new, a story of him having to accept that it's time for his characters to grow and mature that he can't protect children from the dark reality of life. It also coincides with Jennyâ€™s journey herself, a young girl who has always solved these little safe mysteries, but now she has a real life mystery one with actual consequences where she or other people can get really hurt or worse die, itâ€™s a story that challenges her worldview and pushes her to the breaking point it.

Its themes of growing up and having to make difficult decisions and seeing the consequences of them and learning to admit when you're wrong, there are also some pretty good lessons like the bonds of friendship and learning that people are complicated and they don't have to be this one thing. Itâ€™s all done very well in this story as well as brought to life by an excellent cast of characters.

I like the dark aspects of the story, especially when we come to the part of the minors and this one particular minor and his death that's pretty gruesome once you read it. The references in this game were good like these is a cute reference to Agatha Christie and the whole game feels like a reference to classic children mystery literature like Encyclopedia Brown and the like.

The characters are all very good, very well written and quite enjoyable. Jenny herself is a pretty good character, she can come off as a little bit bratty and a bit of a know it all, but at the same time she's generally sincere and wants to do good and wants to prove that she is capable, but she's not perfect she makes mistakes and does foolish things, but she learns from them and can admit when she's wrong and apologizes. Sheâ€™s a well-written and flushed out character that you can root for.

I also like her cousin Suzie Glatz, when we first meet her we assume that she's this popular girl and her only qualities is she's very rich, popular, caring, but a bit of an airhead. [spoiler] But then we find out that she's actually a genius, but she hides it as she's afraid what everyone would think about her, especially her parents due to the fact that her father is sexist, so Susie has to hide this part of herself. There's also this good part where Jenny discovers Susie's first place science trophies that she has to hide. I also really like the fact that despite being a scientist Susie is still a teenage girl who really loves pink, stuffed animals, fashion and boy bands, but also loves science and making inventions, it makes her feel like a more flushed out person. [/spoiler] I also like CJ he's a conspiracy UFO nut, but he's generally funny and entertaining to watch and a good person just not all together.

The gameplay is very good, itâ€™s a sort of choose your own adventure game mixed with puzzles and mystery solving. Basically as you go through the game there are certain times when a character asks you something or you will have to make a choice on how to react, it doesn't really change the story by much and certainly doesn't change the ending. But it gives you more insight on the mystery or of a character, which can help expand the story on a second playthrough. 

There's also a mystery solving aspect where you have to interrogate a suspect and deduce what they were doing by asking them questions about what's on their person, it makes you feel like a real Detective. There is also a puzzle aspect with both regular and environmental puzzles which help break up the gameplay.

The puzzles are all very good, not overly complex and hard but it does require a good brain bit of work and having you think about how to solve them and paying attention to your surroundings and the story, but if that doesn't work you can brute force your way through it but it's not bad.

The graphics/art style are really good and very beautiful with a nice cartoonish/ book feel to it, with its vibrant and beautiful colors and plenty of very beautiful scenery and set pieces that just makes you want to stop, look and just take in the atmosphere. The levels are all very good quite diverse with plenty of nice touches and bits of scenery that make Arthurton feel like a real lived in town, it just looks great and kind of reminds me a little bit of Gravity Falls in certain places.

The music is very good with plenty of nice tracks to listen to that fit the game very well. The voice acting is very good; it's quite believable with no character sounding wooden. Also I swear CJ's voice actor sounds a lot like Christopher Lloyd.The game also has a collectible aspect where you can find stickers, little pieces of art and such in the game if you care about that kind of thing, it doesn't really derail the gameplay or story it's just a little side thing you do you can do if you're interested.

I also love the fact that when you pick up the art but have to say quit the game or restart the level the art is still going to be counted as picked up, so you don't have to waste time picking all that art again

Okay then the dislikes, there are some bugs in the game nothing really game breaking that a quick restart can't fix, I do appreciate the fact like I said if you pick up the art and you have to restart a level the art is going to be counted as picked up even if you replay that level.

I also wish the game had a skip dialogue button, I say that because after beating the game for the first time I went to collect all the other achievements, but I had to sit through the whole dialogue again to get those achievements and there was no option for me to get through it. Don't get me wrong I get the reason why, but I feel like there should have been an option to skip the dialogue once you've beaten the game for the first time. The game story also ends on a cliffhanger that hasn't been resolved yet, but I don't really mind it especially since the Creator already stated they're working on the sequel.

Okay with that said Jenny LeClue â€“ Detectivu is a really good detective adventure game; it has a really good story, very good characters and really good graphics/art style. So I recommend this game especially if you like mystery games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198251611334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 783, 'last_played': 1706306993}
review:
What a beautiful game! : ) If you are looking for interesting story, humor, chill puzzles and wonderful art, this is the game for you! If you play a lot of mystery games or read detective books you will guess most plot twists but discovering the secrets of Arthurton is still a wonderful experience. 
Shout-out to Suzie for being so cool and [spoiler] waiting in the graveyard! [/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198301994997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1851, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1617, 'last_played': 1710189303}
review: This game literally caused me to spiral down a midcentury modern mindfuck rabbit hole that I have not been able to crawl out of since. I first played it in 2021 and immediately became OBSESSED with the charming characters, the incredibly beautiful backgrounds, the atmospheric music, and the brilliant story. Every element of the game feels well thought out, and if you look at the gallery, it's clear that everything was designed with love and intense care. I've been searching for something to fill the Jenny LeClue shaped hole in my heart for over two years now, and nothing has come even remotely close. HIGHLY recommend, but embark on this journey at your own riskâ€“â€“it might just change your life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015534506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 760, 'last_played': 1705828780}
review: This was a very delightful game to play. I love the cartoon graphics, and the voice acting is spot on. The story was laid out very well, and it kept me engaged. The controls are easy. The only real negative thing I have to say about the game would be the magnifying glass function. For the most part, it's for finding gallery items (concept photos), stickers for your journal, or postcard segments that you put together. It gets annoying to find these as there are over 60 of them, and there's an annoying animation that plays while finding them. The way the game ended was kind of disappointing, but it does make me want to play Jenny LeClue 2. From what I've seen over the internet, it is currently in production, so hopefully we see part 2 soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561199253174521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 858, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1707120839}
review: Very chill, enjoyable game, love that you can choose to have the timer on responses or turn it off for even more of a relaxed game play. The art style is really great, and I love that there is voice acting for everything, it's easy on the eyes to not have to read the text and then hunt for clues! Would definitely recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561199410733326', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 933, 'last_played': 1705702434}
review: So much fun, but be advised, this game may keep you playing longer than you anticipated. It is like reading a fun mystery novel, you keep wanting to know more so you keep going.  The animation style is endearing and really lovely. The mechanics are easy to use and in-game actions and activities are easy to understand. The writing is top notch, the voice acting is good, and the humor is safe enough for kids, but still enjoyable for adults. I hope they make a sequel for the game, I'd love to dive back into this world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012502146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 708, 'last_played': 1676035362}
review:
I've started playing "Jenny LeClue".
I quite like the concept. It's like your kid version of Sherlock Holmes. You have to search scenes and observe NPC's for clues, then you get to make deductions by combining those clues. It's all pretty basic, perhaps way too easy for weathered adventurers or Sherlock fans, but it's all brought in a very crisp and funny way.
The graphics kind of remind me of "Return to Monkey Island" and "Oxenfree", there's something pointy and geometric about it all. There are plenty of Nickelodeon influences in the cinematography, with fast zooming in and out, camera swerves, etc. The voices are okay, only sometimes they seem to play at double speed or something.
Luckily the game is subtitled, and it even has Dutch localization. Though it's not without its errors, like "thirty" being translated as "three".
The gameplay took me some getting used to, since there's no mouse control at all! Intuitively I kept trying to move the mouse around, but due to lack of a controller I have to play using the keyboard. After I reassigned the keys, it got a bit easier but still, I'm not used to searching a screen using only arrow keys...
The game has an autosave function but it doesn't save after each interaction, so if you want to quit, you'll have to keep an eye on the save logo in the lower left corner. The first time I had to watch an entire dialogue all over again.

5 hours into "Jenny LeClue" I'm quite amused. It's a fun game that surprises me with its variety of little puzzles and more action-oriented or platformer type puzzles. In some ways it reminds me a bit of "Forgotton Anne".
Tragedy struck and now I'm on a very serious mission. I found some unexpected allies, but basically I'm still going from clue to clue. There are lots of collectables to be found like art and stickers but to be honest I haven't done anything with them yet.
There was this one scene involving a lie detector where I was expecting one particular lie to be surprisingly labeled as the truth, but the story didn't go there. I guess it would've made the game a bit too dark perhaps.
Right now I'm steering a boat between all the rocks on the lake. Luckily it's fun again, but a little after I started it was more frustrating because I thought I just had to reach the other side. Then suddenly I reached a dead end, and I had to look up what the deal was. Turned out I had to do something all the way back at the start first, at a place that I didn't even notice, so I had to backtrack, go into the completely opposite direction from the start (moving away from the finish) and then yes, it linked but a previously found cryptic message. But like I said, it wasn't obvious to me.
Jenny's in-game journal seems to be keeping tabs on how I play the game, and mostly I get the profile of "CEO", I guess meaning that I'm playing it very businesslike.
It's an engaging story.

Finished "Jenny LeClue" in a little under 12 hours!
I had to explore the lake a lot longer than expected. Then I found my way to the cemetery and finally through the old mines. I discovered strange technology all over town, which kind of reminded me of the TV show "Lost". It even started with a hatch in the ground.
There was lots of crawling and climbing and pushing and pulling and dangling and jumping... Yes, this second half of the game was even more of a platformer, and the gathering clues and making deductions was pushed a bit to the background. But that doesn't mean the game stopped being engaging and interesting. There were new and interesting puzzles, like aligning radio waves and decoding messages.
Then comes the ending, and the "To be continued" screen! Well, I was prepared for this, it's the only thing about the game I knew about, so it wasn't as disappointing as finishing the first "Syberia" game was for me. The mystery has been lifted somewhat, but there are still many strange things to figure out. Everything has been enveloped in a "Twin Peaks"/"Thimbleweed Park" type of atmosphere. I do hope that sequel will come out one day, because even though lots of the game was pretty easy, I enjoyed it far more than I expected.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071480387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1704879291}
review:
Das Spiel ist nicht schlecht, aber die schiere Menge an positiven Bewertungen nÃ¶tigt geradezu zu einem gewissen Ausgleich.

Positiv am Spiel ist ganz klar die audiovisuelle PrÃ¤sentation und damit hÃ¶rt es leider auch schon auf.

Die Geschichte des Spiels ist in Ordnung auch wenn sie viele Fehler, UnmÃ¶glichkeiten und Ãœbertreibungen enthÃ¤lt. Die RÃ¤tsel sind lÃ¤cherlich einfach. Wirklich schlecht sind die Charaktere. Jenny ist kein Kind, obwohl sie halb so groÃŸ, wie die Erwachsenen ist. Wenn die Hauptfigur die FÃ¤higkeiten eines Erwachsenen haben soll, darf man diese nicht als 12-jÃ¤hrige darstellen, nur weil es besser in die Geschichte passt. Dann ist einfach die Geschichte schlecht geschrieben.
ALLE anderen Charaktere sind blass, langweilig und stereotyp oder einfach idiotisch (Suzie Glatz ist der schrecklichste Charakter aller Zeiten!!!).

author: {'steamid': '76561198077179782', 'num_games_owned': 1807, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1703986311}
review:
A bit like an easier version of Ace Attorney Investigations with some unfortunate padding (press A to clear an obstacle, crystal mines I'm looking at you) and similar taste for terrible (read awesome) puns. As all the other reviews will tell you it ends on a cliffhanger (and what I can only guess is a ME3 parody). 

Now where's part 2?

author: {'steamid': '76561198885600894', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 833, 'last_played': 1702669906}
review: I found the cut scenes to the storyline quite frustrating. The puzzles were fun enough, but sometimes repetitive. I feel quite cheated that instead of neatly wrapping up the story the creators added a whole new ridiculous level to the story at the end and left you on a cliffhanger. I won't be playing the second game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198209493469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 873, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 824, 'last_played': 1702313187}
review:
I love this game. Donâ€™t get me wrong. The writing is great. The characters are loveable (mostly). I want to be immersed in Arthurton. I do. 

But for the love of all things unholy, having to stop every five seconds to search for a gallery item is seriously ruining the immersion. This is a flagrant abuse of the magnifying glass search function. The actual search for clues, sure. The postcards, I could live with. But having to stop and search for this many gallery items is really spoiling it for me, since you actually need it to progress you canâ€™t just ignore all search prompts. 

That said, Iâ€™d still recommend the game. But if you ever make a second one , donâ€™t repeat this again. Itâ€™s well known to be so annoying Iâ€™ve seen memes on Reddit of it (not that that should be anyoneâ€™s marker of taste).

author: {'steamid': '76561198025470334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 990, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 990, 'last_played': 1610836904}
review: A game like this rides on its characterization and humor, in addition to its puzzle mechanics, and it is gratifyingly good at all of it.  I enjoy the silly people in their lovely and well-illustrated world, while the variety of puzzle interactions keeps things from becoming repetitive, even as the game is balanced to ensure the player succeeds all way through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107014278', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1700536880}
review:
voy a tratar de ser breve, pero adelantando que este juego me dejo un sabor agridulce

lo bueno: historia atrapante y bien contada, personajes y voces bien cuidados, ambientacion y arte detallado... se nota el cariÃ±o que le pusieron al juego

lo malo: ritmo muy lento, el personaje es lento y encima al escalar lo es mas, para colmo hay partes donde no te deja correr... la historia quedo inconclusa, osea que no hay final, hay que esperar otra entrega (si es que la va a haber)

en resumen:
Me force a jugarlo porque queria ver el final de la historia y porque me encariÃ±e con los persoanjes, osea que me tuve que fumar el ritmo lento que tiene para al final tener que mirar como la historia queda inconclusa... no se sabe si dj tiene razon, ni quien es el hombre del sombrero, ni porque la madre y dean hicieron lo que hicieron, ni si suzie es realmente la amiga de jenny, ni si la familia de suzie tiene que ver con todo el experimento, ni si el padre de jenny esta vivo o es un holograma... y es por esa razon que no lo recomiendo, un juego relativamente corto que deja miles de huecos argumentales y que fuerza al jugador a esperar una segunda entrega (la cual ni sabemos si va a existir)

author: {'steamid': '76561198032791041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1010, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1711220999}
review:
a really fascinating collection of highs and lows. every aspect of the art design is superb. the writing is a positive skew mixed bagâ€”the dialogue is fun until it's a bit grating, and the plot is unexpectedly good until the ending, lmao. I do absolutely hate the metafictional author-as-narrator framing, though. the cute upsides to it do not remotely make up for how annoying I find the author character, and how much I'd prefer Jenny, the title lead, to be canonically "real" and not framed exclusively through the male narrator's perspective.

I don't feel it's fair to ding the game for its relatively straightforward game mechanics, because that's what this type of game this is, and it often reminds me of an extremely souped up Humungous Entertainment game in that regard, which I very much enjoyed as a kid. very much scratched that Spy Fox itch

overall: very glad I played, very impressed with how it improves throughout the middle, and am very mad at the ending

author: {'steamid': '76561198140252875', 'num_games_owned': 460, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1697813223}
review:
First played this game on Switch. Enjoyed it very much then, got it on Steam recently, it's just as good as I remembered. Everything looks beautiful, the characters have actual depth, the story is gripping. 

Main nitpick: the game is at its best when Jenny needed to interact and talk with other characters (her chemistry with [spoiler] Suzie [/spoiler] particularly was fantastic). These scenes became fewer as the game progressed. I think the devs realised this as well since they [spoiler] gave her a walkie talkie with Suzie [/spoiler] (very much appreciated, it's never annoying, and the choices Jenny makes [spoiler] when talking to her [/spoiler] in these scenes feel like they actually matter as well).

author: {'steamid': '76561198060462028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 926, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 926, 'last_played': 1696097949}
review: Chill and fun, good story and GREAT voice acting. Easy controls for a noob gamer like me :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198032105360', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1656, 'last_played': 1696565366}
review:
Excellent whodunit with an earnest & intrepid female protagonist for kids 9 to 13 y/o, but I've enjoyed watching every minute. We encountered some plot bloat here and there along with the occasional obtuse puzzle, but nothing impassable and never enough to detract from the overall story and gameplay. Engaging characters and solid voice acting carry players through some adult themes inflected by youth insecurities about death and object impermanence, but they're modulated with context and feathered by tasteful poetic humor. The story and art department created swimmingly pleasant design that unfolds as a consonant whole rather than scads of creative puzzle gameloops bolted together with an artistic gestalt. Fun stuff.

We hope there's a sequel in the LeClue universe, but we hope the developers take time to rest and congratulate themselves after such a triumphant entry.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052236689', 'num_games_owned': 843, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 625, 'last_played': 1696107285}
review: The game is kind of open ended without a sequel currently in sight. However, the level of open-ness is acceptable and the game itself is really cute and fun for the casual point-and-clicker.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991760521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1695518896}
review:
One of those times where I really wish Steam had a neutral/ambivalent rating.

The big headline reservation here is that this is only half a game. The story abruptly ends on a frustrating cliffhanger just as the story is starting to really hit a satisfying third act. That would be frustrating enough for any game, but itâ€™s downright concerning with a very short indie game that took a very long time to make and has been minimally communicative about the sequel.

Aside from that, the game is a delight. Gameplay-wise itâ€™s a very chill adventure game that isnâ€™t challenging but is fun. But the story absolutely grabbed me and made me want to know what was going to happen next. So this is kind of a Schrodingerâ€™s recommendation: if the sequel comes out and is great, this is an easy recommendation. If the game never gets resolved, this is gonna haunt me as a case of squandered potential.

review:
Was soll man sagen..... Ich habe Jenny LeClue jede Minute genossen. Egal ob man bei einem VerdÃ¤chtigen nach Hinweise sucht oder die teilweise frechen Dialoge von Jenny. 
Die RÃ¤tseln sind nicht schwierig und die Geschichte ist Ã¤usserst interessant.
Was mich Ã¼berrascht hat, war das Ende. In diesem Spiel geht es zuallererst, das wir einen Mord untersuchen mÃ¼ssen, in der unsere Mutter verwickelt ist. Dann aber kurz vor dem Ende kommt eine unerwartete Wendung, dass die ganze Geschichte auf den Kopf stellt. Was genau werde ich natÃ¼rlich nicht verraten aber das wird im zweiten Spiel das grosse Hauptthema sein und ich freue mich jetzt schon riesig auf diesen zweiten Teil.

Ein negativen Punkt mÃ¶chte ich noch erwÃ¤hnen: Das suchen nach den Galleriebilder, Postkartenschnitze und Sticker. Man findet sie einerseits bei bestimmten Punkten z.B. an der Wandtafel, die man untersucht (finde ich in Ordnung) und Ã¼berall auf dem Weg. Gerade diese finde ich doch etwas nervig, da man quasi immer wieder kurz anhalten muss, die Lupe-Suchfunktion einschalten und diese dann findet und anschliessend einsammelt. Das finde ich doch nervig wenn ich einfach in den nÃ¤chsten Raum gehen mÃ¶chte.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021551803', 'num_games_owned': 5281, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1691925793}
review:
[h1]Jenny LeClue: Detectivu[/h1]
[i]On the case for fun in this 'detectively' delightful mystery[/i]

[b][i]Note[/i][/b]: This game was played to completion on my Nintendo Switch.

[b]Jenny LeClue: Detectivu[/b], developed by Mografi, is a delightful and masterfully crafted adventure that proves a captivating journey for players of all ages. With its engaging storytelling, charming characters, and innovative gameplay mechanics, and generous dollops of laugh-out-loud humour, it stands as a shining example of how indie games can deliver an unforgettable gaming experience with incredibly memorable and well fleshed out characters.

[u][b]Narrative Brilliance[/b][/u]:
At the heart of [b]Jenny LeClue: Detectivu[/b] lies an enthralling narrative that is woven with meticulous detail and unexpected twists. Players assume the role of Jenny, a young and aspiring detective, as she delves into a web of mysteries that interlace her quaint hometown. The story seamlessly blends elements of mystery, suspense, and coming-of-age themes, keeping players eagerly searching for clues and unraveling the enigmatic plot. The characters are richly developed and relatable, making their journeys and struggles genuinely endearing.

[u][b]Unique Gameplay Mechanics[/b][/u]:
The game cleverly merges traditional point-and-click adventure mechanics with innovative choices that impact the story's progression. Players are encouraged to engage in inquisitive exploration, detective work, and puzzle-solving. The "Narrative Focus" mechanic, which allows players to choose Jenny's actions and shape the story's direction, adds a layer of agency that feels both rewarding and consequential. This balance between player input and guided storytelling creates a dynamic and immersive experience.

[u][b]Visual Charm[/b][/u]:
[b]Jenny LeClue: Detectivu[/b] boasts a distinctive art style that blends whimsical illustrations with a touch of dark undertones. The hand-drawn environments are brimming with life, filled with intricate details that invite players to explore every nook and cranny. Character animations and expressions are wonderfully expressive, enhancing the emotional depth of the narrative.

[u][b]Puzzles and Challenges[/b][/u]:
The game presents an array of brain-teasing puzzles that perfectly complement the detective theme. From deciphering cryptic codes to piecing together clues, the challenges feel organic to the narrative and provide a satisfying sense of accomplishment when solved. The difficulty curve strikes a balance between accessibility for newcomers and engaging complexity for seasoned puzzle enthusiasts.

[u][b]Voice Acting and Sound Design[/b][/u]:
The voice acting in [b]Jenny LeClue: Detectivu[/b] is a standout feature, with each character's voice perfectly matching their personality and adding depth to their interactions. The background music and ambient sounds further enhance the game's atmosphere, contributing to moments of tension and emotional resonance.

[u][b]Innovation and Replay Value[/b][/u]:
[b]Jenny LeClue: Detectivu[/b]'s unique approach to storytelling and its impact on the narrative offers immense replay value. Different choices can lead to divergent outcomes, encouraging multiple playthroughs to fully explore the branching paths and uncover hidden secrets.

[u][b]Conclusion[/b][/u]:
[b]Jenny LeClue: Detectivu[/b] is a shining example of indie game craftsmanship, delivering a captivating blend of storytelling, engaging gameplay, and distinctive artistry. With its memorable characters, intricate mysteries, and player-driven choices, it proves that even in the vast landscape of gaming, smaller titles can shine as bright beacons of creativity and innovation. If you're a fan of mystery, puzzles, or simply a well-crafted narrative, [b]Jenny LeClue: Detectivu[/b] is an outstanding adventure well worth embarking on.

[u][b]Pros[/b][/u]:

- Intriguing and well-developed narrative with unexpected twists.
- Unique "Narrative Focus" mechanic adds player agency to the storytelling.
- Charming art style and expressive character animations.
- Thoughtfully designed puzzles that complement the detective theme.
- Strong voice acting and immersive sound design.
- High replay value due to branching paths and choices.

[u][b]Cons[/b][/u]:

- Some players may find certain puzzles challenging, potentially leading to frustration for those seeking a more casual experience.

[h1]One word or phrase to sum up the experience[/h1]
[i]Thrilling mystery with a wicked sense of humour boasting an incredible cast of characters you can't help but fall in love with.[/i]

[h1]Performance/Bug related incidents[/h1]
[i]None experienced during my playthrough.[/i]

[h1]Similar to games[/h1]
[i][b]Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney Trilogy[/b], [b]The Case of the Golden Idol[/b], [b]Syberia: The World Before[/b][/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197973305685', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1691369801}
review:
A nice adventure game, with a fantastic presentation and a very funny writing.

The gameplay is not very deep (and it's definitely not a real detective game), but it's a pleasure to follow the interesting story and to influence it, since it offers choices to make along the way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198322516618', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 742, 'last_played': 1691163243}
review:
This game is AWESOME. It's a simple adventure game with some puzzle element but nothing complicated really. Very accessible for children! The voice acting is amazing and the adventure is intriguing. I loved it so much! It's actually quite long (12 hours or so) but there is no ending yet. Though that should not discourage you because it's still an amazing experience and I'm looking forward to see the sequel!

Works amazingly on the Steam Deck.

---- PT-BR ----

NÃ£o consigo expressar em palavras a experiÃªncia que foi jogar Jenny LeClue. Eu o adquiri na promoÃ§Ã£o apÃ³s ler a review de uma Curadora que sigo e comecei a jogar com 0 expectativas. Foi aÃ­ que me surpreendi. 

Os grÃ¡ficos e a arte sÃ£o lindos, coloridos. Os personagens sÃ£o cativantes e possuem caracterÃ­sticas (qualidades e defeitos) que os diferenciam e faz com que vocÃª se apegue a eles. A histÃ³ria Ã© envolvente e te prende, de forma que eu me vi jogando seguidamente atÃ© concluir (e jÃ¡ estou ansiosa para mais!!). 
Os puzzles sÃ£o simples, o que torna a experiÃªncia mais satisfatÃ³ria para casual gamers (nem todos querem jogar jogos desafiadores o tempo todo e estÃ¡ tudo bem). 

O jogo progride num ritmo muito bom, nÃ£o se torna repetitivo e o recurso de "scrapbooking" com os adesivos colecionÃ¡veis acrescenta um charme extra.

Enfim, foi uma jornada engrandecedora, tanto para mim quanto para a prÃ³pria Jenny. Com certeza vale a pena jogar. 

---- EN ----

I can't express how much I enjoyed playing Jenny LeClue. I got it on sale after I read a review from a Curator I follow and I started playing with 0 expectations. Man was I suprised. 

The graphics and art in general are gorgeous, colourful. The characters are captivating and each have their own characteristics (qualities and flaws), which makes you get attached to them. The story is great and gets you hooked, in such a way that I found myself playing continously until I finished the game (and I'm already looking forward to more!!). 

The puzzles are simple, making the experience more satisfying for casual gamers (not everyone wants challenging games all the time and that's totally fine).

The game has a good progression, it doesn't get repetitive and the "scrapbooking" feature with the collectible stickers adds an extra charm.

It was an amazing journey, for me and Jenny likewise. It's totally worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561199015956681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 832, 'last_played': 1690050993}
review: Overall a fun game, I enjoyed playing it and will likely play it through at least once more to see what changes when different choices are made. However I got it on sale for $4 and I feel that was a fair price. I certainly would not have paid $20, especially now knowing that this is only episode 1. As curious as I am how the story continues, if episode 2 costs the same amount I will be waiting for another large sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000275990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1039, 'last_played': 1689991679}
review:
Jenny LeClue Detectivu is a great point and click adventure game. The story is well written and intriguing and the art and voice acting are great. This game is a gem, one of the best narrative adventure game I ever played. Unfortunately the puzzle are not challenging enough but the game is so charming that is not that important.
Highly recommended.

!!!! This is just episode one of two, the game doesn't have an end. 
In the store page, at the end of the game description there is a disclaimer about the episode, it should be at the begging of the game description.
This is a little frustrating , especially because it looks like it will take some years before episode 2 will be out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198979027083', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 759, 'last_played': 1687615366}
review:
The Game was very fun. The ending destroyed the game for me. but if you can handle an open end go for it. There are some nice details and you will be entertained.

+ great Voiceover
+ nice music
+ fun characters
+ interesting story (you really want to solve the case)

- no ending, like leaves you REALLY disappointed
- no solution or explanation 
- decisions do not really effect the story
- I guess the sequel will never come
- weak animation

Important hint: ITS POSSIBLE TO RUN.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056272272', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1004, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1004, 'last_played': 1685728455}
review:
This game has wonderful art, charismatic characters (any Suzie stans?), and wonderful storytelling: both the overarching writer and his character parallel as well as the in-game plot and mysteries are fantastic. The dialogue and voice acting was well done, the colors and landscapes were beautiful and immersive, and most importantly, I enjoyed solving the big mystery with Jenny as the game carried on and rooting for her and the town.

The biggest problem with the game, as other reviews have mentioned, is the ending. I understand why it ends there - because that's where Arthur chose to end his novel - but there isn't any follow-up by Arthur at the end implying a sequel, just the end credits saying "to be continued..." and then nothing further from the developers, even today.

Another thing to note, though not discouraging, is that one of the story-related achievements, "Such Great Heights," was bugged for me, not to mention that achievements are a bit repetitive and mindless. Some of the mutually exclusive achievements make sense, but the ending choices don't. I also didn't like how the game emphasized "choosiness," but in the end, none of your choices ACTUALLY mattered. People still helped you even if you played like a jerk, some scenes played out regardless of your choice the exact same way (to the point dialogue didn't make sense), and you could still find all the same secrets and content without the items that are meant to help you along the way. "Choosiness" is more of a fun side aspect than an actual mechanic. Even at the end, the conclusions you draw are insignificant as Jenny will continue her denouement regardless of what you input. 

Some of the scenes (especially if I backed out and then continued from the main menu) were bugged beyond belief. [spoiler]While sneaking into her house, it took me a moment to realize when I was caught before that, even though the game didn't save, it somehow remembered me getting caught, so when I tried sneaking into the house undetected this time, I still had an invisible prompt to mimic something before I could continue her inner dialogue and enter the house.[/spoiler] In this same respect, some visuals were bugged, but again, as the storytelling is this game's biggest strength, that was fine by me.

Despite the unfulfilling ending, I'll still give this game a positive review and recommend it because it WAS so fun to experience. I just really hope there is a follow-up so the story can come full circle. Either way, if and when this game goes on sale, I highly recommend it. Without the promise of a sequel, though, it doesn't seem worth $20.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160609031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 998, 'last_played': 1685696827}
review:
+ Well-written characters, splendid humour
+ a lot of decisions that serve for replay-value
+ gorgeous graphics, atmospheric locations
+ collectibles and customizing for younger players
- some back-tracking
- some puzzles might be repetitive
- no inventory puzzles, no spreading dialogue-trees
- overall linear

Nonetheless a great experience for fans of child-detectives and spreading mysteries. And fortunately, a sequel is already in the works!

author: {'steamid': '76561198267725605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1682802160}
review:
The art, characters, and game-play mechanics are all *chef's kiss*
It is a very fun game that I was invested in the whole time I played it. Also, Jenny is just such a 
likable protagonist. Her sarcasm and back and forth with the narrator are great. Definitely give this game a go if you have the time!
The ending is more "to be continued" than some may like, but I think the game answered enough of the important questions for now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094432643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 1201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1201, 'last_played': 1683427860}
review:
Cute game I recommend playing once. More than that... not sure. If you're an achievement hunter trying for 100%, this might be incredibly frustrating, EVEN with a guide, just from the unskippable cutscenes (as cool as some of them are). Also not recommended if you hate cliffhangers, because this is Episode ONE: the "end" is a "To Be Continued" [exception: if you're reading this from THE FUTURE when all intended installments have been released]

Story: Author of a beloved but becoming less beloved children's book series, Jenny LeClue, has to write a drastically dramatically different book to pick up sales or be cancelled, so he must write in a MURDER. Jenny has to deal not only with this sudden change of tone (imagine if this happened to, say, the Berenstain Bears or Captain Underpants!) but also the murder itself, which is a case she thought she wanted but in fact learns she did not want at all.

Pros:
+ very beautifully animated!
+ easy to like Jenny, despite her inherent antagonism toward Suzie, in particular (merited, in a few instances)
+ great voice acting
+ puzzles aren't particularly difficult (other than the stuff like finding every single bonus item for the achievements)
+ CJ XD XD XD 

Cons:
- aforementioned unskippable cutscenes
- controls take some adjustment to learn, even on a game controller (luckily, nothing requires a huge amount of dexterity)
- the DRAMATIC magnifying glass effect and the tap/hold animations get a bit tedious
- decisions don't really affect the game (not even the final ones)
- little confused who is the target audience, since it feels like it could be aimed at kids but Jenny swears a lot (the light swears, d*mn and h*ll)
- don't really get how the LITERAL MAZE is a "lake" but writing it off as Finklestein is a hack
- NEED PART TWO NOW PLS

tl;dr: Absolutely recommend if the whole series is done, maybe recommend if only part 1 is released, depending on how you feel

author: {'steamid': '76561198132276974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 1347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 702, 'last_played': 1683680085}
review:
Jenny LeClue - Detectivu, man that title is fun to say, has a couple major glaring flaws, but otherwise was a really great adventure game with a pretty bizarre but interesting premise.

In an odd twist, Jenny LeClue is actually not a story about the titular character but instead the author that wrote her, Arthur Finklestein. See, Jenny is a fictional character that he's created as the star of a Nancy Drew pr Hardy Boys style mystery novel series which has run for a good 30 years. However, his books are no longer selling and his publisher warns him that he has one chance to write a darker and more mature mystery that will capture the minds of today's youth or his series will be cancelled. That mystery is the story we get to play as Arthur struggles to write something that goes against the entire ethos of his series up to that point.

The narrative structure of Jenny LeClue is actually very interesting as there exists three separate levels of story-telling going on simultaneously. You have the literal story that Arthur is writing about Jenny's adventure to solve her first murder, the story of Arthur coping with the changes his publisher is forcing on him, and Arthur's self-doubts reflected within the story as the characters and the story go in different directions than the ones he wants to send them on. The mystery itself is interesting as Arthur clearly didn't get by for 30 years by pandering; he knows perfectly well how to build tension and suspense and how to weave it together with drama and comedy. However, there's also an interesting, if not especially deep, examination of the relationship between the art and the artist. Arthur clearly care about his characters, wanting them to be safe and happy, and it's clear that he's the kind of guy who just wanted to write stories that would give people good feelings and brighten their day. Though, due to the changing times, he has no choice but to put them through hardship and suffering or lose his series forever. And if you feel that along with him as the characters feel just as real as Arthur does since we are actively playing Jenny in the story that he's writing, and unlike a lot of these creator/created narratives, it is a complete story that doesn't intersect with reality at all. I give all the credit to Mografi's writing staff for making this premise work and for managing to make the story meaningful as well as entertaining.

Now we have to talk about the ending. It's pretty much the worst part of the game because you make an important decision and then the game just ends without any kind of resolution. Apparently the devs are planning a sequel and using the usage data from the final choice to decide how to open the next installment, however I still feel like they could have put in a cutscene to wrap up the part of the story with your choice taken into account. Even if the next game contradicts it, it would still be better than the non-ending we were given. 

Gameplay is a lot less complicated to talk about as it pretty much all on rails and mostly consists of traversal mixed in with different recurring mini-games. This is not a true detective game, rather a detective themed walking sim in the form of a side-scrolling adventure which is fine. You can still interrogate people by examining the details of their body, make deductions based on your observations, pick locks, rewire electrical panels, decode radio messages, etc. It's actually an impressive amount of unique interactibles. There's nothing complex that'll make you scratch your head, but the game mostly has good pacing. You do spend a bit too long wandering through dark tunnels in the last third of the game.

Overall, I really enjoyed Jenny LeClue. It had a really engaging story with some fun and well-fleshed out characters. Hell, I didn't even talk about Suzie, maybe the best character in any game and not good for your heart with how sweet she is. I'd recommend this game to anyone who doesn't mind a game being fairly laser-focused on the story, and I'd recommend everyone keep an eye out for the sequel if it ever happens.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065646629', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 612, 'last_played': 1682572873}
review:
Great artstyle and presentation, and while the cast of characters is fairly small, they're all entertaining enough for the roles they serve. Gameplay is mostly standard for a mystery/puzzle game. The magnifying glass mechanic is pretty underutilised for story, it's mainly just a collectable finder. 

My only real issue with the game is the ending. I get wanting to sequel bait with a cliffhanger, but this was too much, resolving almost none of the story except the initial mystery, and making the last two choices (as of writing) entirely pointless. If this was a series with regular entries to it, I'd let it go, but the game came out almost four years ago and there's still no sequel so for me the incredibly abrupt ending was like throwing a wet blanket on my enjoyment and kind of soured the experience. If I'd known it ended on a cliffhanger like that, I'd probably have held off buying it until I saw a "part two".

Still recommending it because it's still a beautiful looking game with interesting enough writing, but damn if that ending doesn't knock it down a few points.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045972619', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1693738040}
review: It has some funny bits, and is generally engaging.  But what is not fun is that it doesn't have a save option, and so if you had to quit at some point you are returned to the "level" you were in and have to start the level over.  The jokes aren't nearly as much fun the second time, in my opinion.  Also it is really not mouse-friendly, and apparently the intention, unfortunately not stated at the outset, is that a controller should be used.  I don't have a controller and try to avoid controller-oriented games.  If you don't mind switching from mouse to controller depending on the game, this should be less of an issue for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171096442', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 824, 'last_played': 1680485789}
review: Great game! Really enjoyed the storyline and by the end I was at the edge of my seat during the cut scenes, couldn't wait to find out what would happen next. A very satisfying mystery to unravel in addition to all of the smaller puzzles. Felt like a good amount of content overall. The art is gorgeous and the voice acting is excellent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198213948784', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1046, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1046, 'last_played': 1680314176}
review:
This game is fun, the puzzle are interesting although not super challenging (although that may depend on player age) and the story is interesting. I love the different locations, especially the mines, and the art style. I would recommend this for other people who like fun detective mysteries. 

When presented with options of how to move ahead, I feel like they actually matter and aren't just about saying a different line for the sake of it. I'm looking forward to coming back and trying different answers in some key spots. 

My only two qualms with the game are 1) Jenny can still be pretty mean even when I'm trying to pick what looks like the nicer/friendlier option 2) The magnifying glass mechanic feels backward: you can make it pop up at any time but it won't zoom in or do anything unless the game has prompted you to tell you there's something nearby (which you cannot see, you have to rely on the game prompt). There are times when I can see stickers, but the game won't let me interact with them. This seems like the perfect spot to reward the player with the magnifying mechanic because they actually have spotted something they want to investigate further. Most of the gallery items or postcard shreds are picked up by notification, I might as well skip the magnifying glass part. Or at least have these invisible ones less frequent. There are times when the game tells you "YOU HAVE TO RUN IT'S AN EMERGENCY - oop there's something nearby! stop and scan the screen!" and then it's just a sticker. Like the collectables are cute but you don't know if it's just a collectable or scrap of paper you need to reveal something more and it interrupts the pacing/sense of urgency in the gameplay. This is a really long complaint for what is really a small mechanic that is mostly inconsequential but it's like the only thing I have a problem with and that I feel like the developers could fix for game two.

There's going to be a game two, right?

author: {'steamid': '76561198011233147', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 824, 'last_played': 1678924735}
review:
I really tried to NOT like this game. Because, it's not like I WANT to like every game I've spent my money on. Nah. I like to know that I've wasted time and money on something terrible. I really, really tried, but..... disappointingly I ended up LOVING it.

This game surely has a lot of stuff going for it, though not completely without flaws.

It's kind of hard to explain this completely. It is cute and funny, then suddenly turns dark and mysterious. It is emotional and thrilling and clever and artsy and puzzling and adorable and weird and lengthy and wonderfully narrated and has a totally inconclusive ending. In other words this game is the definition about it being about the journey more than about reaching a goal. Because, WOW, was that ending a punch in the stomach.

That being said, I thoroughly loved almost everything about the game until that that very last part, and there is a second part in development that hopefully brings us a conclusion to all the questions we are left with.

There are some aspects of the game that are incredible. The voice acting in this game is one of the best I've ever come across in any game. They make the story even better and really hits on the punchlines and narrations they do. Fantastic job.  There are interesting puzzles, deductions, interrogations and conversations. Several choices that can be made throughout. Secrets to be found. Enjoying and fulfilling... for the most part.....

Because, some of them feels unnecessary. Some puzzles are just there to stall you a little and take nothing but simple clicking to complete. I feel there could at least be some more ingenuity to those. Some of the choices you get changes nothing or very little to how the story progresses and seem to be there just for separate achievements. Some of the collectibles you have very limited access too, and must be found on your first try or you miss out. You can of course go back scenes you've already been to to make different choices (achievements) or to try your hand at missing collectibles again, but I simply don't like the idea of hiding stuff where you will not have access to all the time, at least in a chapter/scene. Some choices are portrayed as very important choices, but seems to not make any difference, except for a possibility that might make some changes in the next game? I don't know.

I had a great time playing this game and would easily recommend anyone who likes point & click adventures and puzzle games alike to play this gem. Just beware of a disappointing ending, and you should be set for a joyful ride.

I'd rate this game a 8 out of 10 (would have been higher if ending was better)

So, even if I enjoyed this game, we are lucky to be able to have different opinions, so if you are sitting on the fence, make sure to check out several reviews before making your decisions to get it or not.

Happy gaming :o)

TJ

author: {'steamid': '76561198137566954', 'num_games_owned': 785, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1678830802}
review: You know that feeling when you are starting to play some game expecting it to be pretty good, but it turns out to be absolutely fantastic? That is the case with Jenny LeClue: Detectivu. It is one of the better adventure games I've played, with great characters, pleasant gameplay mechanics, satisfactory puzzles, nice humor and gorgeous art direction. Highly recommend if you like adventure games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145093114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1678754178}
review: It's fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004078165', 'num_games_owned': 1525, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1678497922}
review: While this game was pretty fun... I hate to do this, but I'll have to give this one a thumbs down.  This game did a great job of being entertaining and also had a nice art style, but the ending is really what ruined it.  I ended up having even more questions and there was zero closure. And to top it off, they slap you with a big "to be continued" expecting you to buy a second game without even feeling like you've solved anything with this one. I would've been happy if they at least closed this game with most of your thoughts and loose ends being resolved, and then showing how there's still more to be solved in the sequel.  Don't make it so that everything we worked for in this game gets solved in the next game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079830133', 'num_games_owned': 47, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1678243396}
review:
I'm on the fence with this one - leaning more towards positivity.

On the one hand, the game itself is really fun to play. The art style is beautifully done. The story built in a way that made you want to keep playing to see what would happen next. And I love collecting things - so the search for stickers and postcards was great!

On the other, Jenny is the worst...I really struggled to get on her side. I actually have a note that says "Now I get where Jenny gets her awful-ness...her mother is terrible". ALL OF THE LADDERS were insane...holy moly. And I can't believe it ended without a true conclusion - almost 11 hours of play with no final pay off. What a bummer.

Overall, not terrible but not the best either.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994590173', 'num_games_owned': 941, 'num_reviews': 229, 'playtime_forever': 885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 885, 'last_played': 1655421442}
review:
Pretty good. Really charming writing. Fun characters. Good worldbuilding. Gameplay is on the simpler side, but has some fun elements.

Unfortunately, the story doesn't resolve in the first game, but the sequel is in the making. The end is quite an ambitious cliffhanger.

author: {'steamid': '76561198281300977', 'num_games_owned': 360, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1677966322}
review: This game is amazing and really good. I must praise it for what it is and what it puts on the table. Sadly the only problem is the reason I can't recommend it. Even if it is a good peaced story driven game, it has no ending! Like it was cut and wrapped up just before it could tell what was building upon! and I am more than okay with cliffhangers and open endings but this story becomes increasingly interesting the more you play (adding more and more stuff) just to end with nothing of importance really taking place. I know a sequel is in the making but its more likely  the next part of this game so... there. I really want to recommend this lovely game but it just feels incomplete as it is. I Might revise it after the next one finishes but as it stands now, everything is good until the credits roll and you can't believe they just ended it there. I know these games are hard to make but, put a "part 1" at the title, I was really going for a non episodic game when I decided to buy this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014763908', 'num_games_owned': 2519, 'num_reviews': 331, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1676925952}
review:
Just not for me, simple as that.

It plays like a kids game, the story and acting is written and told as if it was a kids game, it's incredibly hand-holdy and you're directed to do everything. If there is a puzzle there is no logic, it's just a matter of going through the 3 or 4 possible combinations until one of them is correct. If you're investigating a place you'll automatically know where the answer or clue is because if a place doesn't have a clue the investigate option is removed after the first time you check it, if there's something there it can still be investigated.

The description of the game makes it seem like something completely different, as if it's an actual investigation game with puzzles but in reality everything is more or less solved for you and you're just there to move the character along while having everything done for you and the story told to you.

As I said it plays like a kids game for young children but I don't think it's fit for a child as for a child I imagine certain parts are quite scary and the overarching theme is murder, crime and horror.
It doesn't fit for me. It's acted and written as if it's a game for young children, it plays exactly like any random kids show for young kids. Huge clash and I don't understand who the audience for that is except for a small niche amount of people, which is great for them I guess.

Maybe it gets better towards the end as some reviews say, but I'm not interested. First impression=not for me at all.

And as a disclaimer: This game does not have an ending or conclusion. This is not a spoiler, this is a disclaimer that you should know before buying. There is no sequel.

Joke of an options menu, there exists 0 excuses for bare-bones, ribbed & empty options menus.

Looking at SteamDB it looks like it's on an 80% sale quite often so if you think this game might be for you then I obviously recommend you get it on sale. $20 for a simple and mostly just purely story, almost visual novel esque ~10 hour game is quite steep.

[h1]Curator page[/h1]

[i]If you liked this review or otherwise found it helpful in deciding whether or not to buy this game, feel free to follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/29162366/]my Curator page[/url].[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198121985991', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 774, 'last_played': 1676693590}
review:
Get ready for a bunch of â€œYou found gallery art!â€ interstitials and poor-at-best gameplay. I adore the artwork, and the writing has some great moments, but you basically just wander around looking for blue dots to hover on. And thereâ€™s a handful of uninspired puzzles to fiddle with. (I wouldnâ€™t say I actually solved most of them, so much as I just moved stuff around until it told me I was done.) The mystery is convoluted, which isnâ€™t necessarily bad if it pays off in the endâ€¦ but the solution (that is, the parts of it that were actually written) was quite unsatisfying for me. Then it suddenly shifts to â€œhereâ€™s a room none of the characters are in, pull one of these three numbered levers, choose wisely!â€ but HOW does one choose wisely with absolutely zero context?

I didnâ€™t enjoy the experience, but I felt invested in the story so I kept playing to the end. And before the most interesting questions about the mystery were addressed, the ones that kept me playingâ€¦ â€œTo be continued!â€ It did NOT end with a satisfying pay off â€” a cardinal sin for a mystery. I suggest taking a pass on this game, I feel it looks a lot better than it actually is.  :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198269169987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1032, 'last_played': 1677098953}
review: I'll be completely honest, at first I hated the controlled which made me stop playing after about an hour. It took me one year to get back to the game and now I'm in love. I like the controlls ( I would NOT change them if I could). The story was at first a bit childish and I didn't understand how godd it would get, I will not spoil but it is getting better and better. I also like the small puzzles, I'm a very casual gamer ant this is right up my lane.  I'm not done with the game but thus far I think it's sollid. I will miss it when I'm done.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970353906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 837, 'last_played': 1673885304}
review:
What a charming game. The Artstyle, characters, story and locations are all oozing with charm.

It helps that everything is written in a humourous, witty style. Especially the back and forth between Jenny and the Narator (among other characters) are a real treat in how the dialogue unpacks. Also the mysteries in this game are actual engaging mysteries. They did their job in that they make the player want to uncover them.

Looking around and exploring the in-game town of Arthurton is always rewarded. The detective element is fleshed out enough to be called engaging, though CSI this is not. The actual puzzling is mostly quite light, with the exception of a few that require some more thought. But this game is never boring, I don't feel it was in need of puzzles that crack your skull. 

I really hope the developer continues this story, while there are points to improve upon in a potential part II, this is a very solid recommendation for anyone looking for a Charming, Funny and Witty Detective story.

author: {'steamid': '76561199017989676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 483, 'last_played': 1710612087}
review:
tho this game never got the greatest attention it has some of the best graphics/art I've ever. If you stop playing the game in any section the whole thing looks like an art peace, and the writing is amazing and funny i caught a few chuckles there and there. and the voice acting for every character there are with i think 18 voice actors. but during through the game there are little mini-games for lock picking, hot wiring, and puzzle solving. but what really got my attention was that your choices get counted and tells you what type of person you are, from protector, to politician, and even more.
 For 20$ it's worth the 4 chapters, plus the collectables from stickers which you can customize your own journal with, to gallery photos of concept art from the making of the game and there is alot of concept art.
So if this interests you, you should buy the game, which a second game is being made following this one, so it will really help fund it.

My only request is that they make plushies of jenny leclue, i would buy that on the spot. <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198983412196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 888, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1676686458}

author: {'steamid': '76561198358098222', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 892, 'last_played': 1673795681}
review:
I've just finished playing this game, and OMG, what an amazing game is was! *Clapping hands*
I almost passed by this title because the steam page is not updated and it doesn't say that it's voice acted. It is voice acted now, and the cast made an incredible job here!
I bought it on a sale, and I'm astonished with the quality of this game: the story, the gameplay, the visual concept, everything! It become one of my favorites on my list, and I sincerely hope this developer continues to bring us more.
Everything is so enjoyable and accesible in this game, things are not over complicated, you can even choose to have time limited (and make it more chalenging) or not. It's well translated, and in a variety of languages.
THis is one of those hidden gems that I cannot recommend enough!
Go play it now!

author: {'steamid': '76561197967101822', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1332, 'last_played': 1706049785}
review:
Jenny LeClue was pleasantly entertaining. Filled with action, voice actors, engrossing story line, choices and morals, superb graphics and puzzles. All the puzzles were potentially difficult, but relatively simple if one looks for "LeClues". Well worth the price for the time it gives back in solid entertainment. However, that ending...

With that said, I did find some rough edges.
1. The tree in the graveyard didn't perform as expected. I was wandering around all over looking for a clue indicating what must be done, but unless you come to a "stop" in the just right area within the graveyard it won't do anything. If you just breeze on through without stopping nothing will happen. Then it must be repeated in the same manner to complete the action.

2. At one point I got stuck between the edge I just climbed up on and a barrel that was left too close to the edge. I had to quit the game and go back in, which put me back to the previous save point.

author: {'steamid': '76561199215834247', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1672263640}
review:
I really wanted to like this game. but.....Game play did not match the game description, game is describes as "game focused on exploration, story, and character, featuring dozens of characters to meet, mysteries and puzzles to solve". I played a little over an hour of the game and the game holds your hand telling you where to click and solves everything for you. There was no independent action on the players part in solving anything other than moving the mouse around until something lights up.
It sounded like the story would be interesting but I just couldn't get over how the game mechanics were working, so not a game for anyone who wants to feel like an actual detective finding the clues or solving the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142054178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1671827198}
review:
Pros:
- cute & often very detailed graphics!
- engaging story, dialogue/banter, framing device!
- full voice acting
- variety of locations
- decent game length
- I liked the puzzles but I can imagine others might find them too easy (I think the intended audience is middle/high school?). 
- choosiness gets recorded in journal
- vibes


Cons:
- WASD controls - why not point-n-click??
- standard walking speed is too slow
- choosiness doesn't actually mean anything (I would have liked to have seen other players' choosiness statistics, like Telltale used to have)
- the sound when Jenny almost walks off a ledge gets on my nerves
- Keith needs more screentime for us to form a bond with him, poor kid
- abrupt cliffhanger ending

author: {'steamid': '76561198035599199', 'num_games_owned': 1983, 'num_reviews': 493, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1670192838}
review:
Absolutely appalling ending.  Let's get that out of the way straight away.  Although I'm still recommending this game, if you can't handle the game coming to a handbrake stop after about 9 hours, with a huge number of questions unanswered, consider this fair warning and steer well away from this game.

With that aside, the journey you take is a very good one.  Well written characters and dialogue, backed up with great voice acting, really propel you along on this excellent adventure.  There are some amounts of padding towards the end, and there's never really much friction from holding you back on this extremely linear game, but this doesn't hold the gameplay back from really shining.  The artwork is also excellent, and there's enough variation in the moment to moment action to keep you engaged throughout.

So, terrible ending aside, there's a lot to like here.

review: Has very nice gameplay mechanics by mixing platform game with puzzle adventure and character- interaction/ -development game. Beautiful graphics with cool 3d zooms out of the 2d platforms and music that fits and is quite likeable. Story is exciting and not easy to guess in advance. author: {'steamid': '76561198074515521', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 979, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 979, 'last_played': 1667518745}
review:
Die Story hat einen guten Leitfaden, doch leider wird man zum Schluss total vom Ende enttÃ¤uscht. Ein unkreatives und geschmackloses "Fortsetzung folgt" ... nachdem ich 16 Stunden im Spiel war. Kann das Spiel daher leider nicht weiterempfehlen, da die Geschichte offensichtlich hier enden sollte und nicht der eigenen Fantasie Ã¼berlassen werden sollte, wenn Jenny doch so Logisch, Rational und Realistisch schlussfolgert! Die Entscheidungen im Spiel haben dadurch null Sinn und machen keinen Unterschied. Wenn es schon mehrere Entscheidungswege gibt, sollten sie auch einen Sinn haben und jeweils etwas anderes auslÃ¶sen und ein eigenes Ende haben. Ich hatte am Ende noch viele offene Fragen unbeantwortet und wenn der Autor so auf Happy Ends steht, hÃ¤tte man auch eins machen sollen und nicht gezwungener maÃŸen jemanden sterben lassen und ein offenes Ende lassen. 
"Fortsetzung folgt" wÃ¼rde nur passen wenn die  Geschichte wirklich noch potenzial hÃ¤tte fÃ¼r einen zweiten Teil, was sie aber nicht hat. Ich bin grad sauer und enttÃ¤uscht...

author: {'steamid': '76561197992694498', 'num_games_owned': 2769, 'num_reviews': 450, 'playtime_forever': 1311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1311, 'last_played': 1660440313}
review:
[h1]Jenny Leclue episode 1[/h1]

Jenny LeClue is a cute adventure game but is it worth playing?
The game starts very cheerfully and from the start it seems like a very pleasant adventure. And honestly it is.

You play as Jenny â€“ a young girl who wants to be a detective. In the beginning you may think the story will be all children's adventure but eventually it evolves into more serious story with twists.
There's also lots of humor which is not bad all and will make you laugh several times at least.

Gameplay is simple. You solve puzzles and explore the surroundings while interacting with other characters from time to time.

Lets start with the puzzles. Often you'll need to examine the area or a person, like their clothes, various objects and then do a deduction. That isn't hard at all and is rather fun connecting the dots.
You also get some traditional puzzles and while they are good and fun, they repeat several times through the game. Same exact puzzles all over again which is disappointing.
Interacting with other characters progresses the story. You also have some choices to make which leads to different responses from the characters. It doesn't change the ending or anything, mostly choices are tied to achievements.
Other than that you'll be running back and forth in a side scrolling manner. It's fun, you'll need to climb, pull/push things, etc.

But there's one huge downside. This game should be called â€œepisode oneâ€ or something like that. The game ends with a huge cliffhanger and you as a player feel betrayed. And it's not your usual cliffhanger seen in movies where after beating the bad guys everyone is happy and you see some baddie appearing again at the very end. No, the cliffhanger feels like the game ends in the middle of the story. That's not right.

Graphically it's a beautiful game. Both the surroundings and characters are nicely drawn. Great variety in locations and nice animations. The game just looks cute, even in the darkest moments.

Sound design is great. Full voice acting with wonderful voices of every single character. Jenny sounds exceptionally well. The voice actors did a great job.
Soundtrack isn't a masterpiece but it's good and accompanies the overall atmosphere of the game very well.

Overall a very good adventure game with extremely disappointing ending. Buy this on sale since you're not getting the full story. Other than that it's worth it for every adventure fan.

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Great story
[*]Wonderful characters
[*]Looks good
[*]Sounds good
[*]Fun and diverse gameplay
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]It's only episode 1
[*]Puzzles repeating themselves
[/list]

review:
Einfaches Mystery Adventure fÃ¼r alle die kein Bock haben LÃ¶sungen extern zu suchen und somit alles aus eigener Hand lÃ¶sen kÃ¶nnen (ohne Kopfschmerzen und genervt sein von der Unlogik der RÃ¤tsel:). 
Jenny ist ein unterhaltsames Spiel, welches mit hÃ¼bscher Grafik, hervorragender Voice-Vertonung und einer interessanten Story punkten kann. Leider haben sich die Entwickler beim Ende herzlich wenig engagiert und deshalb fÃ¤llt die ganze Story am Ende flach wie ein Plunder zu Boden. Auf gut Deutsch, man hat das Finale komplett versemmelt. Sehr schade. 
Hatte persÃ¶nlich aber Fun. Empfehle es wegen dem schlechten Ende nur mit 5/10.
